heading: market mayhem continues
subheading: the economy continues to sizzle, which means there are fears of more interest rate hikes, which means investors are selling their shares in everything. and despite a late rally that trimed losses, the dow and nasdaq continue to dive.
author: wired staff
text: new york -- u.s. stocks dropped for a second consecutive day wednesday as new economic data and comments from a federal reserve official intensified concern the central bank will jack up interest rates at its policy-setting meeting this month. the fed's beige book summary of the economy added to expectations that the central bankers will drive up borrowing costs to keep inflation from accelerating. the summary said an acute shortage of workers pushed up wages in march and april."we're less than two weeks away from the fed meeting and there is a growing constituency that the next rate hike will be 50 basis points and that's bad for equity markets, allegedly," said arthur hogan, chief market analyst at jefferies & co.a government report showing orders for u.s. manufactured goods rose a higher-than-expected 2.2 percent in march fanned the flames. what's more, william mcdonough, new york federal reserve president, said the u.s. economy is starting to show signs of stress and that, especially in relation to the world economy, is exhibiting signs of imbalance and strain.the dow jones industrial average ended down 250.99 points, or 2.34 percent, at 10,480.13. the new york stock exchange turned on program trading curbs when the index slid past the 200-point mark.the nasdaq composite index lost 78.15 points, or 2.06 percent, to 3,707.30 with a deep drop in the stocks of some leading technology companies on a profit warning from software maker novell (novl).among the biggest decliners in the dow were financial services group american express (axp), which fell 6-1/16 to 142, automaker general motors (gm) down 5-5/16 to 88-1/16, and computer maker hewlett-packard (hwpk) lost 5-11/16 at 132-1/2.only five of the dow's 30 stocks managed to climb as investors beat back the retail, energy, financial, technology, and consumer products sectors.measures of the wider market also suffered with the standard & poor's 500 index down 31.19 points, or 2.16 percent, to 1,415.10."it is hard for people to get a lot of enthusiasm for the market when they don't know what the federal reserve might do," said peter coolidge, senior equity trader at brean murray & co. the central bank's policy-setting committee meets on may 16 to decide whether to raise interest rates for what would be the sixth time since last june. a growing number of analysts are forecasting that the central bank will opt for an aggressive 50-basis point boost to slow the economy.that comes just before federal reserve chairman alan greenspan speaks before the market opens thursday to the federal reserve bank of chicago's conference on "the changing financial industry structure and regulation: bridging states, countries and industries."retail stocks were hammered on concern that higher interest rates will crimp consumer spending. also, goldman sachs downgraded 12 major retailers, including the world's largest retailer, wal-mart. home improvements retailer home depot (hd) slipped 2-3/4 to 53-7/8 and wal-mart (wmt) dropped 4-1/8 to 53-3/8.
